sample.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a small part or amount of something that is examined in order to find out something about the whole
sample.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: They took a blood sample to test for hepatitis.
I’d like to see some samples of your work.
sample.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a small amount of a product that people can try in order to find out what it is like
sample.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: free samples of a new shampoo
sample.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a small group of people who have been chosen from a larger group to give information or answers to questions
sample.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: The sample consisted of 98 secondary school teachers.
Out of a random sample of drivers, 21% had been in an accident in the previous year.
a nationally representative sample of over 950 elderly persons
sample.translation[0].definitions[3].def: a small part of a song from a CD or record that is used in a new song
sample.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Her latest album makes extensive use of samples from a wide range of acid jazz tracks.
sample.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: He compared the samples with a blood sample from Mr Green.
They analysed soil samples collected from streams.
Archaeologists are studying DNA samples from ancient Egyptian mummies.
The study took samples from workers at four nuclear plants.
He said he had once fainted when giving a sample of blood.
All the samples were tested for bacteria.
sample.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to taste food or drink in order to see what it is like
sample.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: a chance to sample the local food
sample.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to choose some people from a larger group in order to ask them questions or get information from them
sample.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: 18% of the adults sampled admitted having had problems with alcohol abuse.
sample.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to try an activity, go to a place etc in order to see what it is like
sample.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Here’s your chance to sample the delights of country life.
sample.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to use a small part of a song from a CD or record in a new song
sample.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: Many of his songs have been sampled by other artists.
sample.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a number of people or things chosen from a large group to take part in studies that provide information about the whole group
sample.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Of a sample of executives in 600 companies, 15% had no plans to do business in the EU.
The survey was based on a random sample (=a number of people or things chosen without knowing anything about them) of households from all income groups.
The agency interviewed a representative sample (=a specially chosen group including several different types of people) of 1,003 people in the city.
sample.translation[2].definitions[1].def: a small amount of a product that people can use or look at in order to find out what it is like
sample.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: He used the product after receiving a free sample in the mail.
We were shown some sample pages for the new book.
sample.translation[2].definitions[2].def: a small part or amount of something that is tested in order to find out something about the whole
sample.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: A sample of the water showed that it contained high amounts of sodium.
sample.translation[3].definitions[0].def: to ask a group of people chosen from a larger group questions, in order to get information or opinions from them, so as to better understand the larger group
sample.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: Four different groups of adults were sampled for the survey.
sample.translation[3].definitions[1].def: to try a small amount of a product in order to find out what it is like
sample.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: Here’s your chance to sample our latest product.
